Issues.Title: docs - broken design at layout - container, hero and section ?
Issues.Body:
Hi,

while studying the docs in order to use it in a web app, i have found (_imho_) broken design pages:
- https://bulma.io/documentation/layout/container/
- https://bulma.io/documentation/layout/hero/
- https://bulma.io/documentation/layout/section/

These mentioned pages are shown equal in current google chrome and firefox (on windows).

Is this "broken design" wanted?

non-broken design:
If you load e.g. [doc footer ](https://bulma.io/documentation/layout/footer/), the doc itself in centered between ToC overall (left) and ToC current side itself (right). This looks as desired.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "docs - broken design at layout - container, hero and section ?" (#3456)

Issues.Title: Add missing variables for content customization
Issues.Body:
<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is a **improvement**.
<!-- Improvement? Explain how and why. -->
This introduces 2 variables to customize some parts of the `<table>` in "content"

### Proposed solution

<!-- Which specific problem does this PR solve and how?  -->
<!-- If it fixes a particular Issue, add "Fixes #ISSUE_NUMBER" in your title -->
This introduces 2 variables to customize some parts of the `<table>` in "content":
  * `$content-block-margin-bottom`: To customize bottom margin of "block" elements (especially tables in our case)
  * `$content-table-body-last-row-cell-border-bottom-width`: To customize the size of the bottom border of the body last row cells

As I'm not completely familiar with your naming conventions, variables name might be renamed, just let me know.

### Tradeoffs

<!-- What are the drawbacks of this solution? Are there alternative ones? -->
<!-- Think of performance, build time, usability, complexity, coupling…) -->
I don't think there is any tradeoff.

### Testing Done

  * Checked contributing guide
  * Modified .sass file locally
  * Compiled without vars overload => Ok, same style as before
  * Compiled with vars overload => Ok, expected style for me

### Changelog updated?

No.

<!-- Thanks! -->
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "Add missing variables for content customization" (#3455)

Issues.Title: Grouped fields have no margin in case of nested fields
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about a bug in **Bulma**

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.9.2
My **browser** is: Chrome 95.0.4638.69
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
<!-- I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? -->

### Description

When using nested fields in a form, the bottom margin has bug that it is zero for child fields. If the screen width is high enough, such that the grouped field is in one row, everything is fine. However, on mobile, whenever the group is broken into two lines, the last one has zero margin to the bottom. Meaning that, if you stack grouped multilined fields together, there is no space between them on a mobile device. The issue https://github.com/buefy/buefy/issues/1313 probably has the same root cause. There is mentioned that the issue is due to the margin-bottom: 0 at the last child.

See the jsfiddle to reproduce the problem https://jsfiddle.net/dmx83v65/ If you shrink the viewer width until the multiline field breaks the line due to responsive layout, you will see that there is not space between the two grouped-multilined fields (between input with placeholder 2 and input with placeholder 3)

Here is a picture of what happens:

![bulma](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9616291/144458250-c340339f-007d-4837-bd91-8731cea07ff9.png)

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Create a grouped multilined field
2. Create a child field (nested)
3. Make a copy of the whole nested fields and paste to the end

### Expected behavior

The spacing is not broken in case of nested fields

### Actual behavior

There is no space after the multiline field
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Grouped fields have no margin in case of nested fields" (#3453)

Issues.Title: Bug? Card with an overlay, loses bottom round corners
Issues.Body:
### Overview of the problem

Bulma framework issue.
Not browser related, tested on both Firefox and Chrome.
Bulma latest, version 0.9.3,

### Description

When using a `card` with a `card-image` in it, when adding an overlay (`is-ovelay`) the bottom round corners are losing their 'roundness'.

### Steps to Reproduce

The following codepen demonstrates the issue: https://codepen.io/avirancodepen/pen/NWaKbQo

### Expected behavior

4 round corners

### Actual behavior

2 round corners
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Bug? Card with an overlay, loses bottom round corners" (#3451)

Issues.Title: Use "@extend %unselectable !optional" to avoid this error.
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem
SassError: The target selector was not found.
Use "@extend %unselectable !optional" to avoid this error.
   ╷
14 │   @extend %unselectable
   │   ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
   ╵
  node_modules/bulma/sass/helpers/other.sass 14:3  root stylesheet

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

<!-- This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** -->
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->

<!-- My **browser** is: -->

I am using SASS 1.43.4
This is in a Vue, Nuxt aplication.
This is my pacakge.json:

"dependencies": {

    "bulma": "^0.9.3",

    "fibers": "^5.0.0",
    "husky": "^6.0.0",
    "lint-staged": "^10.5.4",
    "prettier": "^2.3.2",
    "sass": "^1.43.4",
    "sass-loader": "^10.2.0",
    "stylelint": "^13.13.1",
    "stylelint-config-prettier": "^8.0.2",
    "stylelint-config-standard": "^22.0.0"
  }

<!--
1. First Step
2. Second Step
3. and so on...
-->

Issues.Title: Tough question regarding image ratios and blocks for spacing
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma**. This is a **question** ### Overview of the problem This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** I'm using Bulma **version** 0.9.3 My **browser** is: Firefox 94.0.1 (64-Bit) ### Description **Short**: I need to find image ratios, where one big image has the same height, like two small ones with a `block` spacing in between. **Longer Version** I am programming an image blog with a gallery, looking e.g. like this: ![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36443026/141296666-543e32c9-0cde-4111-a2f0-19f740eed710.png) For this I am using `card`, `block` and `column` elements. For the top row, I use code like this: ```html
``` This will all work fine, until I combine two images next to one big one like so: ![grafik](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/36443026/141297527-86b9fb3e-ed53-4c95-bcc1-d78e271f7a53.png) As you can see, the spacing introduced by the `block` variable will make the two right images taller in height than the left big image. No matter what ratios I am using, they never end up aligning perfectly. Even if I found a perfect ratio, is it correct that the `rem` used by `block` for spacing might screw up my layout on different devices anyway? The code I use is the following: ```html
``` My questions: 1. Is this problem solvable, when using `block` with `rem` as spacing? 2. How can I create custom ratios to perfectly compensate for the spacing in between and is there a way to calculate these ratios? 3. What would the smart approach be? ### Steps to Reproduce See above ### Expected behavior Find image ratios with normal `block` spacing, which do not create offsets like in the images above ### Actual behavior The `block` spacing introduces an offset, which looks bad
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Tough question regarding image ratios and blocks for spacing" (#3444)

Issues.Title: Bulma Fixed Position Elements
Issues.Body: This is about Bulma. ### Overview of the problem This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** I'm using Bulma **version** [0.9.2] My **browser** is: Chrome I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate** ### Description I have created a fixed position button for moving to the top, using manual CSS. Is there a way to do this natively within Bulma? I try to avoid custom CSS whenever possible. Here is the fixed position button, which always remains at the bottom right of the page: ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/37300313/140992320-5784efce-ba55-4471-add9-9f1f52400cea.png) Here is the HTML I used to accomplish it: ` ` Due to the way my pages in this app can have wildly diffrent page lengths, I needed this button to always remain in the same spot and to float above all other elements. After a few interations the above CSS accomplished what I needed. I searched for a way to do this with Bulma and could not find one.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Bulma Fixed Position Elements" (#3443)

Issues.Title: title/subtitle rendered in single line in Hero container
Issues.Body:
Hi, 

I noticed that the both "hero is-halfheight" and "hero is-fullheight" will make title/subtitle inside "hero-body" rendered in a single line instead of two. We can workaround this by wrap them in an extra `<div>` tag. Not sure if this is the intended design or a bug. But if it is intended design, it probably should at least be noted in the documentation and state the reason why we need this?

See https://bulma.io/documentation/layout/hero/#halfheight-hero and https://bulma.io/documentation/layout/hero/#fullheight-hero
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "title/subtitle rendered in single line in Hero container" (#3442)

Issues.Title: Issue with Tabs component in RTL
Issues.Body:
When I was trying to use the Tabs component in a hero layout while I was using `bulma-rtl.css` and I noticed a small problem with the `border-radius` of the tabs elements when the tabs container has a `.is-boxed` class, It seems like we don't need a different `border-radius` for **RTL** version, since the codes in the referenced codes below are trying to make it upside down instead of **RTL** or **LTR**, Then it's better to have only a single `border-radius` for both versions.

https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/a6cd4f302edcd60d438c9dad1db4b39ab08da7a9/sass/components/tabs.sass#L97-L100

**Problem:**

![Problem](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/53313989/139674435-8487de19-468b-4fa5-aaba-7f4e4bbd5b4f.png)

**Expectation:**

![Fix](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/53313989/139674439-ede595f3-5f09-4e1f-989c-b99b8371a298.png)

I'll try and open a pull request for a fix.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Issue with Tabs component in RTL" (#3437)

Issues.Title: Update with-sass-cli.html
Issues.Body:
Using flag option "source-map" results in error using sass --version 1.43.3

Expected: "Watch" and "Build" process of sass to run without errors.
What Actually Happens: The console throws an error: flag option "source-map" should not be given a value. 
Solution: When running the command for "Watch" and "Build" remove the flag option "source-map"

Issues.Title: Is it possible to set Hero height according to screen size?
Issues.Body:
I would like to split the home page in 2 columns for wide screens  (desktop) and 2 rows for narrow screens (mobile) 

Hero seems to be the convenient but I am missing -is-halfheight-mobile

Would it be possible to add this class. If I'm misusing Hero please tell.

### Proposed solution

Issues.Title: 'is-hoverable' seems to be broken on tables
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma**. ### Overview of the problem This is about the Bulma **CSS framework** I'm using Bulma **version** 0.9.3 My **browser** is: FireFox, Chromium ### Description When the `is-hoverable` class is applied to a table, the table rows do not change colors anymore on hover. This is also visible in the [docs](https://bulma.io/documentation/elements/table/). ### Steps to Reproduce 1. Create a simple table ```html
One Two
Three Four
Five Six
Seven Eight
Nine Ten
Eleven Twelve
``` 2. Add `is-hoverable` to the `table` element 3. Try hovering the mouse over a row ### Expected behavior A slight color change on each `tr` element on hover. ### Actual behavior No color change!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "'is-hoverable' seems to be broken on tables" (#3430)

Issues.Title: Multiple css files
Issues.Body: Bulma is currently only [one CSS file](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/master/css/bulma.css). It would be way more useful if there were multiple CSS files, meaning there is one file for each component,  element, or concept just like the [SASS files](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/tree/master/sass). If this was also a thing for CSS we could just import **only** the CDN files we need instead of one big CSS file. When I use my Bulma CSS on [Google Lighthouse](https://developers.google.com/web/tools/lighthouse), I am told that there is lots of unused CSS. This makes the website way slower. The best solution would be those multiple CSS files. I know this is already a thing for SASS, but it is complicated to set up, especially for static site generators. I would strongly appreciate it if someone made this change possible. Please let me know what you think of this suggestion, and how likely it is to be implemented. I hope you understand my problem and how to fix it.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Multiple css files" (#3429)
